Award.AwardTitle: Distribution and Moment-Robust Optimization Models and Algorithms

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Optimization models and methods are widely used in decision problems. Incorporating parameter uncertainty is important in constructing representative optimization models. This parameter uncertainty may be described by a probability distribution, the moments of a probability distribution, or using bounds and confidence intervals on moments. When estimating uncertain parameters, information is also available on the error distribution of the estimated parameter. The research objective of this award is to study properties and develop algorithmic methods for solving multivariate optimization models that incorporate parameter uncertainty using limited knowledge on their distribution, and the parameter estimation errors. The optimization models will be based on using parameter distribution moment estimates. The models will incorporate moment estimation errors using a suitable penalty approach.

If successful, the results of this research will lead to the development of a new class of decision optimization modeling tools with associated algorithmic techniques for solving these models. This award will contribute to better handling of parameter uncertainty in single and two-stage inventory planning models, the classical least squares model, and the models involving objectives described by quadratic functions. A better understanding of algorithmic implications of parameter uncertainty in these problems will provide foundation for handling parameter uncertainty in other application models that use the planning, the least squares and quadratic objectives as basic building blocks. The award will also contribute to the development of computational tools implementing the algorithms solution techniques. Experiments will be performed to validate the algorithms, and to compare the properties of the solutions generated from the models incorporating distributional knowledge with those that ignore this information.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Optimization models and methods are widely used in decision problems. Incorporating parameter uncertainty is important in constructing representative optimization models. The goal of the proposed research was to develop a new class of decision optimization modeling tools with associated algorithmic techniques for solving these models.  A better understanding of algorithmic implications of parameter uncertainty in these problems will provide foundation for handling parameter uncertainty in other application models that use the planning, the least squares and quadratic objectives as basic building blocks. 

Outcome:
The research has fundamentally advanced the field of robust optimization by studying the concept of distributional ambiguity. The research developed novel reformulations and algorithms for solving such problem with general modeling frameworks. The research also showed the benefits of distributional robustness over the classical approach. Specifically, the following major outcomes were achieved as part of the proposed research.

Distributionally Robust Least-Squares: 
We showed that the case where bounds are imposed on the uncertain parameters using the first two moments of a distribution, the least-squares problem can be equivalently formulated as a semidefinite program. We also showed that when the bounds on the distribution are given using the cumulative distribution function of the random data, a semidefinite reformulation is still possible using a sample average approximations. Finally, we showed that when the ambiguity set of distribution is specified using Wasserstein distance of first order, the problem also permits a second order cone reformulation when the support of the distribution is finite.

Distributionally Robust Convex Optimization:
We showed that this two-stage model can be solved to any precision in polynomial time. We also conducted experiments showing the robustness-tradeoff when compared to a model that uses expected value function in the objective without using the distributional robustness constraint. We showed that if a certain distributional separation problem (to generate a distributional cut) can be solved to epsilon-accuracy, then the distributional robust model can also be solved to epsilon-accuracy. We also proposed a randomized algorithm for finding such a solution that finds the distributional cut with high probability to the desired precision.

Distributionally Robust Support Vector Machine:
We developed a distributionally robust support vector machine that searches the classifier that minimizes the sum of regularization term and the hinge loss function for the worst-case population distribution among the ambiguity set. We provided semi-infinite programming formulation of the DR-SVMs and further developed a cutting-plane algorithm to solve the problem. Computational results on simulated and real data show that the DR-SVMs outperform the SVMs in terms of the Area Under Curve (AUC) measures on several test problems. Several of these test problems involve the use of dataset arising from disease classification in human health.

Distributionally Robust Stochastic Mixed Integer Programming:
We developed a novel L-shaped method for solving distributionally robust two-stage linear optimization problems. We further developed this method for solving distributionally robust two-stage optimization problems where the first stage decision variables take binary values, and the second stage decision variables take mixed binary values. We showed the finite convergence of this method. The developed L-shaped method was compared to a cutting surface algorithm, also developed in our previous research. It was demonstrated that for difficult problems the L-shaped method significantly outperforms the cutting surface algorithm which does not take advantage of the structure of stochastic programs. 

 

Human Resource Development Outcome:

The results were presented at the INFORMS national conferences in 2011 and 2012; A mini-symposium at the SIAM Optimization conference in 2014 where four talks were given by the PI and co-authors, INFORMS Optimization Society conference in 2014, and an INFORMS national conference in 2016. The results from this research were also presented at invited talks at the Rutgers-Stevens Workshop on Stochastic Optimization (2011), Argonne National Lab (2012) and Industrial Engineering department at University of Minnesota (2015). A talk was also given at the INFORMS national conference in 2016 on the latest results. Two research papers were published. One technical report has been made available, and one paper is currently in progress.  The results from this research have also been incorporated as part of a new special topics course I have offered at Northwestern University.

The project trained a graduate student (Changhyeok Lee) on the use of distributional robust optimization for decision problems. A second PhD student (Fengqiao Luo) was also initiated to work on this topic. A postdoctoral fellow (Manish Bansal) was trained and has now received an employment as a faculty at the Industrial Engineering department at Virginia Tech.

Societal Impact
The modeling framework was applied to problems in energy system design. Results were developed that allowed to perform sensitivity analysis for such problems. It was found that better design of these systems that can cover uncertain energy demand with greater reliability can be achieved by making minor alterations to the power grid design.
